name: Trieste
fun_fact: Fun fact: Trieste was the main port of the Austro-Hungarian Empire until 1918, and locals still drink coffee like Vienna - ordering a 'capo in b' (espresso with a drop of milk in a glass) at grand caf√© houses that have remained unchanged since the empire fell over a century ago.

hero_dishes.name: Gulasch with Polenta
hero_dishes.description: Hungarian-style beef stew slow-cooked with onions, paprika, tomatoes, and herbs, served with creamy polenta.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Trieste adopted the Hungarian national dish when it was the Austro-Hungarian Empire's only port. The local version uses Italian olive oil and herbs alongside Hungarian paprika, creating a unique Triestino fusion that's neither fully Italian nor Austrian.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Buffet da Pepi (opened 1897, institution for Austro-Hungarian tradition), traditional buffets throughout Trieste

hero_dishes.name: Mixed Meat Platter at Buffet da Pepi
hero_dishes.description: Six different forms of mostly pork prepared using original kettle cooking technique - sausages, roasts, boiled meats, served cold or warm.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Buffet da Pepi has been serving this Austro-Hungarian specialty since 1897 using the same kettle cooking technique. The menu is exclusively meat, reflecting Vienna's influence on Trieste's working-class food culture.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Buffet da Pepi (a true institution since 1897, exclusively meat menu)

hero_dishes.name: Jota
hero_dishes.description: Hearty stew made with beans, potatoes, sauerkraut (crauti), olive oil, and garlic. Sometimes includes smoked pork.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Found from Trieste down to Istria, jota represents the Slovenian influence on Triestino cuisine. The combination of Italian beans and olive oil with Slavic sauerkraut creates something uniquely regional.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional trattorias throughout Trieste, Nerodiseppia (one of Italy's best trattorias)

hero_dishes.name: Fresh Adriatic Seafood
hero_dishes.description: Daily catch from the Marano lagoon to Istria waters - grilled fish, seafood pasta, mixed fish plates prepared simply to highlight freshness.
hero_dishes.origin_story: As a port city, Trieste's Italian side shines in its seafood preparations. While Austrian influence dominates meat dishes, the Adriatic provides exceptional fish prepared with Mediterranean simplicity.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Hostaria Malcanton (fresh seafood favorite), Nerodiseppia (catch of the day from local waters)

signature_drinks.name: Viennese-Style Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Coffee served in the Austro-Hungarian tradition with many variations - capo in b (espresso with drop of milk in glass), cappuccino, macchiato.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed at grand caf√©s like Caff√® degli Specchi (unchanged since the Empire) where elegant interiors transport you to old Trieste. Ordering coffee here is a ritual, not just caffeine.

signature_drinks.name: Friulano Wine
signature_drinks.description: White wine from the Friuli Venezia Giulia region, crisp and aromatic with floral notes.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with seafood at Trieste's trattorias. The local wine reflects the region's unique terroir and winemaking traditions distinct from the rest of Italy.

food_culture_notes: Trieste isn't quite like the rest of Italy - the food is Triestino, pulling from Italian, Austro-Hungarian, and Slovenian influences
Buffets in Trieste aren't all-you-can-eat - they're working-class taverns serving Austro-Hungarian meat specialties
Coffee culture is Viennese, not Italian - grand caf√© houses with Empire-era elegance still dominate
The city's three identities (Italian, Austrian, Slovenian) are felt at every meal
